comments.commentBody: should read: "lions roaring now,"

Mary – Have you noticed that Hillary Clinton has received lots of coverage in recent months despite the fact that she has not announced that she will be a candidate for president in 2016? I have. Some of the articles have appeared on the front page, and some have been open to comments. I did not find the articles to be newsworthy. Another article appeared on the front page on Tuesday discussing a possible 2-woman ticket if Clinton runs. Does The Times have an agenda it is pushing? I believe it does.

@RLS: The press/media generally is chomping at the bit in anticipation of another Clinton run. And yes, The Times has joined the crowd.

What's most troubling about this is that it drowns out the voices of people like Bernie Sanders and Elizabeth Warren.

Instead of worrying about whether Hillary Clinton will run in 2016, Democrats should be working day and night to get their voters out in 2014 and that includes funding candidates running in 2014, not setting aside a hoard for someone they think might run in 2016. We need to get the lion's roaring now, not two years from now.

How is it that conservatives have "too much power" when the President and the Senate are both Democrats?

I don't agree that women are required to be mothers, or that sex is sinful. It is amusing that liberals believe they know what conservatives want, when they really haven't a clue.

State races are easy pickings for the big money that doubles down on local candidates and drives local attitudes. South Carolina has seen a steady drumbeat of political advertising since the Super Bowl, in a state where no race is expected to be close.

Why the daily drone of ads for Haley, Graham; issue ads against Obamacare, new attack ads designed to draw in women--in a state that conventional politics says doesn't need the investment?

The state is now a laboratory for testing messages, ads, polling; campaign techniques. If North Carolina is the poster child for draconian legislation, micro-managing every scintilla of government and rights, South Carolina is the benchmark for campaigns aimed at average white people, a way to pre-assess the effect of conservative ads for the fall.

All of this is in keeping with the expansion of AFP chapters, which keep watch on the process and support specific candidates for races down to school boards (last cycle, Iowa, Colorado, and North Carolina). The shadow governments are being built and pieces of the puzzle are being spec'ed.

Two ironies: one, the media directs attitudes and is isolated from criticism; the ads are also shields and act as drones. This has shifted their messaging. Two, the dark money continues the investment in disbelief necessary to disguise the oligarch message as populism. Unable to win on the racial code, they have found it effective to organize on. Its not the care, it's Obama, The backlash is building.

"UE and US forced them somehow?"

Yes. The insisted on an all or nothing deal. The agreement with the EU (not membership) had to be exclusive, had to be tied to the IMF, and had to be tied to cutting the existing trade relationships with Russia which the EU feared would allow the Russians a back door way into the EU relationship.

Russia by contrast was always willing to compromise on the economic deal, to allow some of both. Compromise was feared by the EU, opposed by the US as contrary to its purpose of hemming in Russia, and so not available to Ukraine.

John -- Thank you very much.

The columnists perform other functions too. 1) They set the agenda of conversation and get it started; 2) They are comfort reading for those who know what thy want to hear and find cognitive dissonance painful, which is a very real human problem; 3) They are an address to which the powerful with an agenda can reliably take their agenda, though this is even more true in other papers than here -- money talks loudly here as in politics generally.

What we contribute is moderation, the middle class to their privileged class.

I was a Peace Corps Volunteer in Moldova in 2003-2004. It has been ten years since I have been back. Obviously, things change, but Mr. Kristof's portrayal of Moldova seems overly-simplistic to me.

The Moldovans' relationship with Russia is complex. The official language is Romanian, but there are parts of Moldova where Russian is the dominate language. Many Moldovans speak Russian as a second language and take advantage of their fluency by going to work in Russia and then send much needed money back home.

Some of the older generation have fond memories of the Soviet Union. They will argue that life was not perfect then, but in some ways it was better than now. Some of these same people will also call Putin a bully. People's views towards Russia are not black and white.

The Moldovans I knew certainly would not have described their government as "plucky." The adjective I usually heard was "corrupt." The feeling was that the politicians did not care about the people. It is not hard to see the Moldovans' point-of-view. Our Peace Corps medical doctor advised us not to eat fish caught in any body of water in Moldova because they were all polluted. Infrastructure was in desperate need of repair. The home of a family I lived with lost power every time it rained hard.

I am not arguing that America should not engage Moldova diplomatically. However, if we do, it must be with a more comprehensive understanding of the country than what Mr. Kristof presents here.

Moldova is a tiny country of 3.5 million people, desperately impoverished, and without a defense of their own. Their new defense minister was quoted in this paper a few days ago saying he did not know how big their army was, but it was at most a few thousand, and had little equipment. Part of it has always been occupied by Russian "peacekeepers" to because that half million does not want any part of the other three million. The Russian peacekeepers already there could overwhelm the whole country in a few days or less.

Moldova is in the belly of the beast already. It does not need defiance and support to fight Russia. It needs to make the best deal it can, just as Finland did after WW2.

That is not bold and brave, it is just the way it is. Never mind "valiant" and "bravest country in the world." That was Georgia attacking Russia, and we barely managed to save them from their lunacy.

Don't get started on the "cause" of Moldova. That does that tiny place no favors. Leave them in peace, with the best deal they can get.

Recall, it was the US and the EU that would not let Ukraine take a middle course, some of the West and some of Russia. Just let Moldova do that. Don't pitch them into the fires.

The First Amendment says the right to free speech shall not be impeded.

So why has all our media been monopolized?

No longer will a person who wants to start a Facebook or a Youtube or a Google be able to compete.

This will also allow mischief to be made against those whose speech that The Powers that Be doesn't want to be heard. They will deny it of course.

Then, there is the question with the rate of advancement in technology, this idea of rationing should not even be an issue. Why are they making an issue of it?

The Founding Fathers had an internet of their day. It was called the United States Postal Service. They felt it was so important for the people to be informed that they let any news journal to use the service free, and because they were performing an essential service to democracy, they were even given tax incentives. The same principle should be applied to the internet. It should be free for all.

This is an attack on the First Amendment, future entrepreneurs, political activists, journalists, and the internet itself.

This statement was made by Tzipni Livni...Israel's chief peace negotiator..about some in the Israeli government.
“There are people in the government who don’t want peace,” Livni said. “Bennett and Uri Ariel represent those who want to prevent a peace process.”
When is Israel going to renounce violence and state the Palestinians have the right to exist.
The palestine liberation organization was formed in 1964 when Jordan ruled the West Bank and Egypt ruled Gaza. So exactly what was being liberated at that time? Certainly not the West Bank or Gaza.

The flying Balalaika Brothers are a real band in Austin who play amazing music , all real good and they do frequently sing in Russian. Texas and Russia might be a good fit, both petrostates, kind alike firm, hardline leaders ( or those who pretend to be). We could be free of Obama, just think, fellow Texans

The only plebiscite/referendum necessary is in the Unites States of America to determine how many Americans would want to embroil themselves in a European conflict where only geopolitics and economic power-plays and not their own interests are at stake.

Wanna take a guess???

Yes, absolutely, give the people of Transnistria the opportunity to join Putin's Petro-state or to become some sort of independent mini-state.  Same thing for the folks in eastern Ukraine, although a referendum there would be more difficult to manage considering the size of the region and the mix of ethnicities which varies from one population center to the next.   On the other hand, such plebiscites need to be internationally monitored and the voters should be required to submit valid proof of residency.  If Moscow refused to go along with this we'd have to say "no deal."  On the other hand, perhaps Putin would also be willing to take Texas off our hands.  Surely there must be one or two Russian-speakers there...

Israel to those parents that they would be protected in the war.  They chose to abandon the country to the war.  Would it make sense to give right of return to those who bet against your country surviving?

Well, I don't where the problem is. If these two factions succeed to work closely and properly, it is good news for all the Palestinians. We should be happy for them, unless Israel and the US are using the division of these groups to gain unfair concessions for Israel. Anyway, good for the Palestinians

MTFTTTT accomplished it the old-fashioned way: Clean living, Golden Rule, locally-grown organic produce.

Food in a tube

It is more important by far for the Palestinians to reconcile among themselves than to remain divided and engage in the US-Israel peace farce. They don't need peace, nor do they need a two-state solution, when it is certain that Israel will eventually cease, because of demographic realities that cannot be wished or negotiated away, to be a Jewish state.
Palestinians are best served by a strategy that facilitates their internal coherence and lets time take care of the externalities.

You read about our military being behind all of those trolls, right, in order to spread disinformation and propaganda. It used to be illegal, probably still is, for the military to do what it has been doing for so long. I include the intelligence agencies when I talk about military.

iwasakow,

Egypt and Jordan had little difficulty in recognizing their borders as part of their respective peace agreements with Israel. Prior to those agreements, those borders had been determined by the I.D.F. on the battlefield.

If you are unaware that the current negotiations are to include final borders between Israel and the Palestinians, it is because you are ignorant of the of the issues to be negotiated.

UNSCR 242 and 338 would be fine places to start negotiations on "secure and recognized boundaries," for both Israelis and Palestinians, if only the Palestinians would recognize them!

That is so naive and ignores history. A recipe for even more intimately vicious conflict, not separated by a "wall." Are you familiar with the history of inter-enthic conflict and massacres during the British Mandate period, when Palestine actually was "one state?" It would the the reverse of what happened in Yugoslavia, instead of separating but forcing mortally opposed communities into unwanted, eternal conflict.
Their long term strategy is oppression and complete world dominance.

This is why America is and will continue to falter.  Keep putting short term corporate gains above long term strategy.  These policies are costing us dearly.  When it comes to internet transmission speeds the USA ranks 31st.  Far behind other places like; Hong Kong, Singapore, Estonia, Hungary, Slovakia & Uruguay. In upload speeds we rank 42nd.  Increase speeds and reliability before asking consumers to pay more for what many parts of the the rest of the world take for granted.

Some other countries have faster pipes because their carriers, unlike ours, started virtually from scratch to create internet infrastructure. Our carriers had already invested billions in legacy infrastructure and have been relentlessly upgrading.   I used to work for a small fiber ISP. We surveyed our usage once and identified a single teenager running a bittorrent server in his room who was responsible for more than half the total traffic for a system supporting 50,000 customers.  The idea that anyone should be able to dump traffic onto a carrier's infrastructure, negatively impacting all other users and pay nothing for the privilege is a twisted joke.

An essential element of any lasting peace will be a unity government of the Palestinian people which speaks for the collectivity and has a mandate to negotiate a peace agreement, which if reached, would stand a better chance of enduring than if the agreement were with one faction, while the other remains intent on disruption. I don't understand how Netanyahu and the US Administration can be so myopic as not to understand this. And that said, a peace agreement with Israel may not even be the first priority of the Palestinians. Just maybe they think they have a right to sort out their governance issues for all kinds of other good reasons affecting their daily lives. That's their internal business to see after.

Excellent news. Palestinians finally figured out that the USA are no honest broker...just  a biased proxy of Israel. Palestine will live as a sovereign country, with or without the tainted blessing of Israel and the US.
Your perspective does not explain explain the terrorism, war, and boycotts directed against Israel from  1947 - 1977 when there were no settlements in the west bank and gaza.
Yeah, Mark, and by now we'd be trying to figure out how to fix all the damage we did to those environments. Until we respect and restore our planet we have no business thinking about space.

Maureen O'Brien -- The environmental problems you mention are one more example of what we have lost.  That damage is due to the same greed that cost us our forward progress in our economic life and in space exploration.  It is all of one pattern.

Looking back, we could have and should have moved out into space far more, with Moon colonies and more. We see that after JFK's great vision, there was nothing. Blank. A void. We spent the resources on wars and preparing for more wars.

Looking back, after LBJ we gave up the dream of social progress. It was all about cutting back, and protecting privilege. We could have and should have "a world where crime, unemployment and mental illness had virtually vanished, where college was free, and laundry was cheap and people ate their stupendously delicious meals."

Instead, we are back to the 1890's in a New Gilded Age of privilege and record breaking inequality and the fall of the Middle Class to pay for the oligarchs. Our kids pay for college so some of the wealthy can have really, really big private jets.

This has been a lost opportunity. It could have been. It should have been. We have only our wealthy and the politicians they bought to blame. The vision was there. It was all possible.
should read: "lions roaring now,"

In recent memory, we've seen great rejoicing over the Arab Spring and Egypt's conversion to democracy; one interpretation is that should not get very excited about this development as it is likely transient.

The political climate and the regulations we operate under today are vastly different than they were back then. That includes the degree to which politicians are beholden to money in politics. The money machine is feeding both sides. It has been for some time. That too, but mostly the inaction of Congress, is what is paralyzing our government.

Had Holder gone after the banksters, how much less support do you think President Obama would have gotten in achieving the few things he has achieved so far?

I'm not excusing any of this. I am merely trying, as Charles does here, to point to the fact that the president and his cabinet can only work with the Congress we've given them. We've given them a horrid opposition party and a not so great Democratic minority. Democratic voters need to clean house too.

PS: I remember the S&L cleanup quite well. I started my career after college right around then.
